{{Infobox person | name = Gerald F. Davis | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1961 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater = [[University of Michigan]]
[[Stanford Graduate School of Business]] in 1990. | employer = University of Michigan | occupation = Business sociologist | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | box_width = }} '''Gerald Fredrick''' ('''Jerry''') '''Davis''' (born 1961) is an American sociologist, and Professor of Sociology at the [[University of Michigan]], known for his work on corporate networks,Gulati, Ranjay. "Alliances and networks." ''Strategic management journal'' 19.4 (1998): 293-317. social movementsLee, Min‐Dong Paul. "A review of the theories of corporate social responsibility: Its evolutionary path and the road ahead." ''International journal of management reviews'' 10.1 (2008): 53-73. and organization theory.Frooman, Jeff. "Stakeholder influence strategies." ''Academy of management review'' 24.2 (1999): 191-205. == Life and work == Davis obtained his AB in philosophy and psychology at the [[University of Michigan]] in 1984, his MA in Sociology from [[Stanford University]], and his PhD in Organizational Behavior at the [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]] in 1990. After graduation Davis started his academic career at [[Northwestern University]]'s [[Kellogg Graduate School of Management]] as assistant professor in 1990, and got promoted to associate professor. In 1994 he returned to the Stanford University Graduate School of Business as associate professor, and got promoted to full professor. In the year 1997–98 he was research fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences in Stanford, California. Since 2001 he is professor of sociology at the [[Ross School of Business]] at the [[University of Michigan]], where he was also professor of management and organizations from 2002 to 2004. Davis described his research interests as "broadly concerned with the effects of finance on society. Recent writings examine how ideas about corporate social responsibility have evolved to meet changes in the structures and geographic footprint of multinational corporations; whether "shareholder capitalism" is still a viable model for economic development; how income inequality in an economy is related to corporate size and structure; why theories about organizations do (or do not) progress; how architecture shapes social networks and innovation in organizations; why stock markets spread to some countries and not others; and whether there exist viable organizational alternatives to shareholder-owned corporations in the United States."[http://webuser.bus.umich.edu/gfdavis/ Jerry Davis] at ''bus.umich.edu,'' Accessed 25.01.2015. == Selected publications == * Davis, Gerald Fredrick, ed. ''Social movements and organization theory.'' Cambridge Univ Pr, 2005. * [[Scott, W. Richard]], and Gerald F. Davis. ''Organizations and organizing: Rational Natural and Open System Perspectives,'' (2006) (sixth edition). ;Articles (selection) * Davis, Gerald F., and Tracy A. Thompson. "A social movement perspective on corporate control." ''Administrative science quarterly'' (1994): 141-173. * Davis, Gerald F. "[https://bing.bc.edu/candace-jones/mb851/Feb12/Davis_ASQ_1991.pdf Agents without principles? The spread of the poison pill through the intercorporate network]." ''Administrative science quarterly'' (1991): 583-613. * Davis, Gerald F., Kristina A. Diekmann, and Catherine H. Tinsley. "[http://webuser.bus.umich.edu/gfdavis/Papers/Decline%20and%20Fall.pdf The decline and fall of the conglomerate firm in the 1980s: The deinstitutionalization of an organizational form]." ''American Sociological Review'' (1994): 547-570. * Davis, Gerald F., and [[Henrich R. Greve]]. "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/231170 Corporate elite networks and governance changes in the 1980s]." ''American journal of sociology'' 103.1 (1997): 1-37. * Davis, Gerald F., Mina Yoo, and Wayne E. Baker. "[http://www.albany.edu/~gangolly/inf720Fall2012/TheSmallWorld.pdf The small world of the American corporate elite, 1982–2001]." ''Strategic organization'' 1.3 (2003): 301-326. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{wikiquote}} * [http://webuser.bus.umich.edu/gfdavis/ Jerry Davis] at University of Michigan. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Davis, Gerald Fredrick}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:American sociologists]] [[Category:University of Michigan alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Northwestern University faculty]] [[Category:University of Michigan faculty]]

page.title: Howard M. Metzenbaum United States Courthouse

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Old Federal Building and Post Office | nrhp_type = | image = File:Howard M. Metzenbaum United States Courthouse.jpg | caption = Howard M. Metzenbaum U.S. Courthouse, 2018 | location= 201 Superior Ave., NE, [[Cleveland, Ohio]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|30|2|N|81|41|33.5|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = United States Cleveland#Ohio#USA | architect = Brunner, Arnold W.; French, Daniel Chester | architecture = Classical Revival | added = May 3, 1974 | area = {{convert|1|acre}} | governing_body = [[General Services Administration]] | refnum = 74001448<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> }} The '''[[Howard M. Metzenbaum]] U.S. Courthouse''' is a historic [[courthouse]] and [[post office]] building located on Superior Avenue in [[Downtown Cleveland|downtown]] [[Cleveland]], [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio]]. Its west side faces [[Public Square, Cleveland|Public Square]] and its north side faces [[The Mall (Cleveland)|The Mall]]. It was formerly the '''Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse''' and also known as Old Federal Building and Post Office.
==Building history==
The Howard M. Metzenbaum U.S. Courthouse, also known as the Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse, is a monumental anchor to Cleveland's Civic Mall. Fronting the Mall and Public Square, it was the first building erected under Cleveland's 1903 Group Plan, which illustrates the urban planning ideals of the [[City Beautiful movement]].<ref name ="GSA">{{cite web|url=http://www.gsa.gov/portal/ext/html/site/hb/category/25431/actionParameter/exploreByBuilding/buildingId/525|title=GSA - Find a Building|date=2009-08-24|work=Howard M. Metzenbaum U.S. Courthouse, Cleveland, OH : Building Overview|publisher=U.S. General Services Administration}}</ref>
New York Architect [[Arnold W. Brunner]] (1857–1925) designed this imposing building under the direction of [[Office of the Supervising Architect|Supervising Architect]] of the Treasury [[James Knox Taylor]] (1857–1929). It is one of 35 buildings constructed during Taylor's tenure (1883–1912) that were designed by independent architects commissioned by the U.S. Treasury Department under the Tarsney Act. The 1893 Act authorized the Secretary of the Treasury to use private architects, selected through competitions, to design Federal buildings. As a process, it manifested the growing demand for greater architectural standards for public buildings and opened the way for additional appropriations to maintain those standards.<ref name ="GSA"/>
As the first building erected under the Group Plan, the federal building was the model for later structures. The Group Plan proposed that local and federal government buildings be placed around a grand Mall. Embraced from the late 19th century into the first decades of the 20th century, the City Beautiful movement had its beginnings with the monumental planning and predominately classical architectural style of the 1893 [[World's Columbian Exposition]] in Chicago. Celebrated architect [[Daniel Burnham]], who was instrumental in promoting the nationwide adoption of City Beautiful Movement principles, served as a member of the design team that produced the Group Plan. Arnold W. Brunner, working as an independent architect, and John Merven Carrère, of the prominent New York firm of [[Carrère and Hastings]], also served on the team. The Federal Building formed one half of the Mall's termination at Superior Avenue. [[Cleveland Public Library|Cleveland's Public Library]] (1925), forming the other half of this terminus, emulates the Federal Building in scale, mass, and general overall appearance.<ref name ="GSA"/>
The building was listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1974.<ref name ="nris"/> On May 27, 1998, the building was officially renamed in honor of U.S. Senator [[Howard Metzenbaum]] of Ohio.<ref name ="GSA"/>
==Architecture== [[File:Courthouse eagle.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|One of the decorative stone eagles at the building's roofline]] The Howard M. Metzenbaum U.S. Courthouse is one of Cleveland's great monumental public buildings, skillfully illustrating the strong, classical characteristics of [[Beaux-Arts architecture]]. The five-story, granite-faced building was constructed between 1903 and 1910. The building covers the entire city block bounded by Rockwell Avenue on the north, Superior Avenue on the south, East Third Street on the east, and Public Square on the west.<ref name ="GSA"/>
Inspiration for the design of this Beaux Arts building came from the [[Place de la Concorde]] in Paris as well as the work of French architect and theorist Francois Blondel. The resulting design presents a [[rustication (architecture)|rusticated]] first floor and {{convert|42|ft|m|adj=mid|-high}} [[Corinthian order]] columns and [[pilaster]]s on each elevation. These massive columns and pilasters define the sequence of window bays on the second, third, and fourth stories. Rusticated stone-arched windows with carved keystones adorn the first story. The more ornate second-story windows are capped with classically inspired [[pediment]]s and [[balustrade]]d sills. The third- and fourth-story window openings have molded surrounds and bracketed sills. Screening the fifth floor is an expansive [[entablature]] capped by a balustraded parapet that rises nine feet. A low-hipped, standing-seam copper roof crowns the building with attic [[dormer]] windows facing the interior light court. The [[parapet]]s are adorned with shields and carved stone eagles at the building's corners.<ref name ="GSA"/>
{{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= [[File:Old Federal Building Cleveland.jpg|210px]] | video1 = [http://www.gsa.gov/portal/content/126585 Power and Poetry: Howard M. Metzenbaum U.S. Courthouse, Cleveland, Ohio], U.S. [[General Services Administration]]<ref name="gsa film">{{cite web | title =Power and Poetry: Howard M. Metzenbaum U.S. Courthouse, Cleveland, Ohio | work = | publisher =U.S. [[General Services Administration]] | date = | url =http://www.gsa.gov/portal/content/126585| accessdate =April 26, 2013 }}</ref> }}
The main entrance to the building is centered on the Superior Avenue facade. Granite steps lead to three rusticated stone arches once fitted with cast bronze doors and ornate bronze lanterns hang from cast bronze brackets. The original doors have been replaced.<ref name ="GSA"/>
Flanking the primary entrance are two important sculptures executed by the famed sculptor [[Daniel Chester French]] (1850–1931). "''Jurisprudence''" is located on the Public Square corner, while ''Commerce'' sits at the corner of East Third Street and Superior Avenue. "''Jurisprudence''" is personified by a mother figure clasping her baby while a criminal crouches in chains. "''Commerce''" is depicted as a female figure holding a model ship in one hand while her other arm rests on a globe representing the opportunity for world trade. At her right is "''Electricity''," symbolized by a female figure holding a magnet catching electrical sparks. "''Steam''," located to her left, is represented by a male figure grasping a wheel.
On the interior, the grand main lobby dominates the first floor as it runs east to west across the entire length of the building. The floors, walls, and vaulted ceiling of the lobby are surfaced with marble. Original chandeliers illuminate the space. The postal service windows are located along the lobby's north wall. Marble stairs wrap around three sides of the elevator shafts, located at the east and west ends of the public lobby. Cast-bronze, spread-wing eagles standing on globes appear over each pair of elevator doors. Corner offices in the upper floors are adorned with impressive murals depicting significant events in the history of Cleveland. Among the magnificent artworks are "''City of Cleveland Welcomes the Arts''" by [[Will Hicok Low]] (1853–1932), and the "''Battle of Lake Erie''" by [[Rufus Fairchild Zogbaum]] (1849–1925). Murals in the ceremonial courtrooms on the third floor are "''The Common Law''" by [[Henry Siddons Mowbray]] (1858–1928), and "''The Law''" by [[Edwin Howland Blashfield]] (1848–1936).<ref name ="GSA"/>
A major renovation project to restore public spaces and modernize the mechanical systems was initiated in 2002. Although the primary activities of the U.S. District Court system have moved to the new [[Carl B. Stokes Federal Court House Building]] a few blocks west, the ceremonial courtrooms in the Metzenbaum Courthouse will continue to be used for public hearings and proceedings. New client agencies moving into the renovated building will include the U.S. Bankruptcy Court, the Office of the U.S. Trustee, and the U.S. Marshals Service.<ref name ="GSA"/>
==Significant events==
*1893: Passage of the Tarsney Act permits the Federal Government to hire private architects through competitions. *1902: The 1858 federal building is demolished to allow for the construction of a new U.S. Post Office, Custom House, and Courthouse building. *1903: The Cleveland Group Plan is presented; construction of the new federal building begins under direction of New York architect Arnold W. Brunner. *1905: May 20, 1905 - cornerstone is laid *1910: Construction is completed. *1911: Building is dedicated *1934: The main U.S. Post Office moves out of the building. *1939: Building is cleaned *1950: The U.S. General Services Administration initiates alterations and construction of additional courtrooms. *1966: Air conditioning is installed, building is cleaned *1974: The building is listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. *1998: The building is renamed in honor of U.S. Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio. *2002: Extensive rehabilitation and modernization of the building to better serve new client agencies.
==Building facts==
*Architect: Arnold W. Brunner *Construction Dates: 1903-1910 *Landmark Status: Listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places]] *Location: 201 Superior Avenue, NE *Architectural Style: Beaux Arts *Primary Materials: Gray granite *Prominent Features: Exterior sculptures "Jurisprudence" and "Commerce" by Daniel Chester French; Ceremonial Courtrooms

'''Ignacio Uría Mendizábal''' (4 January 1938 – 3 December 2008) was a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] [[Basque people|Basque]] [[businessman]] and head of construction company, Altuna y Uría.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7763216.stm Spanish businessman 'shot by Eta'] ''[[BBC News Online]]''</ref>
Uría was shot dead on 3 December 2008 outside a restaurant.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5280323.ece Eta shoots dead businessman working on high-speed Spanish train link] ''[[The Times]]''</ref> The attack was blamed on [[ETA (separatist group)|ETA]]. He had received threats from ETA. Uría had been working on a high-speed train route between the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]] and [[Madrid]]. ETA threatened several companies and their workers involved in the train project as it views such construction as an imposition on the Basque Country by the Spanish and [[France|French]] governments.

[[University of Wisconsin Law School]] | ambassador_from = United States | country = Poland | order = 7th | term_start = June 13, 1933 | term_end = April 23, 1937 | predecessor = Ferdinand Lammot Belin | successor = [[Anthony J. Roosevelt]] | office3=[[United States Ambassador to Luxembourg|United States Envoy to Luxembourg]] | term_start3 = January 17, 1940 | term_end3 = July 18, 1940 | predecessor3 = [[Joseph E. Davies]] | successor3 = [[Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle, Jr.]] | president3 = [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] }} '''John Clarence Cudahy''' (December 10, 1887 – September 6, 1943) was an American real estate developer and diplomat. In the years leading up to [[World War II]], Cudahy served as United States ambassador to [[Poland]] and [[Belgium]], and as United States minister to [[Luxembourg]] and the [[Irish Free State]]. ==Early life== Cudahy was born in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], the son of [[Patrick Cudahy]] the [[meat packing industry|meat packing]] industrialist and Anna Cudahy. He graduated from [[Harvard University]] in 1910 and from the [[University of Wisconsin Law School]] in 1913.{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/10577084/john_cudahy_obit/ |title=John Cudahy, Former Envoy, Killed In Fall From Horse |url-access=limited |newspaper=[[Arizona Republic]] |location=[[Phoenix, Arizona]] |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |via=newspapers.com |date=September 7, 1943 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} Cudahy served during [[World War I]] as a lieutenant in Company B of the U.S. Army's [[339th Infantry Regiment]].{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/10577143/john_cudahy_obit/ |title=Ex-Envoy Is Killed In Fall from Horse |url-access=limited |newspaper=[[Battle Creek Enquirer]] |location=[[Battle Creek, Michigan]] |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |via=newspapers.com |date=September 7, 1943 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} This regiment was part of the [[Polar Bear Expedition]], which was sent to north Russia to intervene on behalf of the anti-communist forces in the [[Russian Civil War#Course of events|Russian Civil War]]. On November 14, 1918, Cudahy led a counter-attack that succeeded in breaking through and routing the 1,000 Bolshevik troops that on November 11 ([[Armistice Day]]) had encircled and [[Battle of Tulgas|attacked]] the 600 American, Canadian, and Royal Scots soldiers who were holding the village of [[Tulgas]] on the [[Northern Dvina River]].{{cite book |title=When Hell Froze Over |first=E. M. |last=Halliday |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] |location=[[New York City]] |date=2000 |pp=13–14 |isbn=978-0739415955}} However, his eventual disillusionment with the campaign in north Russia led him to write (under a pseudonym) the book ''Archangel: The American War with Russia''.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Gbu2DAAAQBAJ&lpg=PT597&dq=%22November%2014%2C%201918%22%20cudahy&pg=PT597#v=onepage&q=%22November%2014,%201918%22%20cudahy&f=false |title=Taboo Genocide: Holodomor 1933 & the Extermination of Ukraine |first=Kris |last=Dietrich |publisher=Xlibris Corporation |date=September 11, 2015 |accessdate=April 27, 2017 |via=[[Google Books]]|isbn=9781499056082 }}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=January 2018}} Back in the [[United States]], Cudahy headed his family's real estate company, building the Cudahy Tower Apartments on the shore of [[Lake Michigan]] in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin|Milwaukee]]. ==Diplomatic service== Between 1933 and 1940, Cudahy served the United States as minister to several European nations. From September 6, 1933, until April 23, 1937, Cudahy served as the American ambassador to [[Poland]].{{cite web |url=https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/people/cudahy-john-clarence |title=John Clarence Cudahy (1887–1943) |website=history.state.gov |accessdate=April 18, 2017}} His time in Poland was marked by a militarily backed government under [[Józef Piłsudski]] and continued tensions between Poland and [[Nazi Germany]] under [[Adolf Hitler]]. From August 23, 1937, Cudahy served as [[United States Ambassador to Ireland|minister to the Irish Free State]], which became the [[Republic of Ireland]] in December 1937. His official title was [[Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary]], and he served until January 15, 1940. In January 1940, Cudahy became both the ambassador to [[Belgium]] and the minister to [[Luxembourg]]. He was forced to leave these posts after Germany occupied Luxembourg and Belgium in May 1940, and the nations set up [[Government in exile|governments-in-exile]]. In 1941, ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine commissioned Cudahy to interview Hitler, which he did at [[Berghof (residence)|Berghof]].{{cite magazine|last=Cudahy|first=John|date=9 June 1941|title=Hitler on Americas: Life Correspondent Interviews Führer on War and the Future|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jUwEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA34|magazine=Life|pages=34–36}} Cudahy later authored the book ''The Armies March'', recounting his experiences in Europe leading up to the war, including the [[Battle of Belgium]] and his meeting with Hitler. ==Death and descendants== Cudahy died in September 1943, when he was thrown from a horse on his [[Brown Deer, Wisconsin|Brown Deer]] estate north of [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin|Milwaukee]].{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/10366688/cudahy_death/ |title=John Cudahy, Diplomat Well Known Here, Dies In Fall From Horse Sunday |url-access=limited |newspaper=[[The Sheboygan Press]] |location=[[Sheboygan, Wisconsin]] |via=newspapers.com |date=September 7, 1943 |accessdate=April 18, 2017}} Cudahy's son, [[Michael Cudahy (electronics)|Michael Cudahy]], founded [[Marquette Electronics]] and became a major philanthropist in the city of [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin|Milwaukee]].{{cite web |url=http://biztimes.com/article/20130513/MAGAZINE03/130519971/ |title=Michael Cudahy receives BizTimes Lifetime Achievement Award |accessdate=2014-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728223043/http://biztimes.com/article/20130513/MAGAZINE03/130519971/ |archivedate=2014-07-28 |website=BizTimes.com |first=Steve |last=Jagler |date=May 13, 2013 }} Cudahy's daughter, Mary Keogh-Stringer (born Mary Toulgas Cudahy), was a successful artist;{{cite web |url=http://www.tributes.com/obituary/show/Mary-Keogh-Stringer-102092851 |title=Mary Keogh-Stringer |date=January 19, 2015 |website=tributes.com |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} the dedication of ''The Armies March'' reads;
for Toulgas Cudahy
whose name was taken from the [[Battle of Tulgas|battle twenty-three years ago on Armistice Day]] in the American war with Russia,
in the hope that her generation may see an enduring armistice.
== Works == * {{cite book |url= |title=Archangel: The American War with Russia |author=A. Chronicler (Cudahy, John) |publisher=[[A. C. McClurg]] |location=[[Chicago]] |date=1924 |asin=B000HCN2XS}} * {{cite book |url= |title=Mañanaland: Adventuring with Camera and Rifle through California in Mexico |first=John |last=Cudahy |publisher=Duffield & Co. |location=[[New York City]] |date=1928 |asin=B000JBZYXS}} * {{cite book |url= |title=African Horizons |first=John |last=Cudahy |publisher=Duffield & Co. |location=[[New York City]] |date=1930 |asin=B00085ORWO}} * {{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SEoEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA75&ots=tZV1cAHmH6&dq=Belgium's%20L%C3%A9opold%3A%20U.S.%20Ambassador%20Clears%20the%20King%20of%20%22Treason%22%20Charge&pg=PA75#v=onepage&q=Belgium's%20L%C3%A9opold:%20U.S.%20Ambassador%20Clears%20the%20King%20of%20%22Treason%22%20Charge&f=false |title=Belgium's Léopold: U.S. Ambassador Clears the King of "Treason" Charge |first=John |last=Cudahy |magazine=[[Life (magazine)|Life]] |date=November 25, 1940 |volume=9 |number=22 |pp=75–83 |via=[[Google Books]]}} * {{cite book |url= |title=The Case for the King of the Belgians |first=John |last=Cudahy |publisher=privately published |location=[[New York City]] |date=1940 |asin=B0096U441Q}} * {{cite book |url= |title=The Armies March: A Personal Report |first=John |last=Cudahy |publisher=[[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner's]] |location=[[New York City]] |date=1941 |asin=B0006D8WOW}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{findagrave|9696250}} {{s-start}} {{s-dip}} {{succession box|title=[[United States Ambassador to Poland]]|before=[[Ferdinand Lammot "Mot" Belin]]|after=[[Anthony J. Drexel Biddle, Jr.]]|years=1933–1937}} {{succession box|title =[[United States Ambassador to Ireland|United States Envoy to the Irish Free State]]|before=[[Alvin M. revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Juha Sipilä |image = Tallinn Digital Summit. Handshake Juha Sipilä (2017).jpg |office = [[List of Prime Ministers of Finland|44th]] [[Prime Minister of Finland]] |president = [[Sauli Niinistö]] |deputy = [[Timo Soini]]
[[Petteri Orpo]] |term_start = 29 May 2015 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Alexander Stubb]] |successor = |office2 = [[Speaker of the Parliament of Finland]] |term_start2 = 28 April 2015 |term_end2 = 29 May 2015 |predecessor2= [[Eero Heinäluoma]] |successor2 = [[Maria Lohela]] |office3 = [[member of parliament|Member of the Parliament of Finland]] |term_start3 = 20 April 2011 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|04|25|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Veteli]], [[Finland]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Centre Party (Finland)|Centre Party]] |religion = [[Laestadianism]] |spouse = Minna-Maaria Juntunen |children = 5 |alma_mater = [[University of Oulu]] |allegiance = {{flag|Finland}} |branch = [[Finnish Army]] |rank = [[File:Kapteeni kauluslaatta.svg|25px]] [[Captain (armed forces)|Captain]]http://www.iltasanomat.fi/kotimaa/art-1288474136351.html Ilta-Sanomat: Keskustan Juha Sipilä ylennettiin kapteeniksi (4 June 2012) {{fi icon}} }} [[File:Juha Sipilä 2015.JPG|thumb|right|Juha Sipilä in Vaasa, 2015]] '''Juha Petri Sipilä''' ({{IPA-fi|ˈjuhɑ ˈsipilæ}}; born in [[Veteli]], 25 April 1961) is the current [[Prime Minister of Finland]]. A relative newcomer to politics, he has a successful background in business.http://www.euronews.com/2015/04/19/opposition-leader-juha-sipila-wins-elections-in-finland/ He has been the [[Centre Party (Finland)|leader of the Centre Party]] since 9 June 2012. After leading the Centre party to victory in the [[Finnish parliamentary election, 2015|2015 general election]], Sipilä formed a [[Sipilä Cabinet|centre-right coalition]] and was appointed Prime Minister by the [[Finnish Parliament]] on 29 May 2015.http://yle.fi/uutiset/mps_vote_sipila_in_as_prime_minister__result_not_unanimous/8025742 YLE News: MPs vote Sipilä in as prime minister- result not unanimous. 28 May 2015 ==Education and military service== Sipilä graduated from [[Puolanka]] [[Gymnasium (school)#Northern European countries|lukio]] (Finland's university-preparatory high school), completing the [[Matriculation exam (Finland)|matriculation examination]] with high marks in 1980.{{cite web| url = http://www.iltasanomat.fi/vaalit2015/art-1427799759029.html| title = Näin Juha Sipilä on muuttunut – katso lukio-, hää- ja lapsuuskuvat| work = Iltasanomat| author=Mika Koskinen | date=March 31, 2015| accessdate = August 4, 2015}} In 1986 Sipilä earned his [[diplomi-insinööri|Master's degree in science (technology)]] from the [[University of Oulu]]. Sipilä has the rank of Captain in the reserves of the [[Finnish Defence Forces]]. ==Business== Sipilä's career started at Lauri Kuokkanen Ltd., first as a thesis worker and later as a product development manager.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} Changing jobs, he became a partner and later CEO at Solitra Oy.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} In 1998, Sipilä started his own business, Fortel Invest Oy. In 2002–2005 he worked as the CEO of [[Elektrobit]] Oyj, then returned to his own business.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} Sipilä was managing director of Solitra in 1992 and became the main owner in 1994. Sipilä sold Solitra to American [[ADC Telecommunications]] in 1996, becoming a multimillionaire from the proceeds. Business ADC Mersum Oy was resold to Remec in 2001.[http://htf.kaleva.fi/index.cfm?j=371030 Yritysuutiset8.1.2004]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}[http://www.kilpailuvirasto.fi/cgi-bin/suomi.cgi?luku=yrityskauppavalvonta/yrityskaupparatkaisut&sivu=ratk/r-2001-81-0935 Yrityskaupan hyväksyminen; Remec, Inc. / ADC Mersum Oy] 26.10.2001 In 1996, Sipilä's income was the highest in Finland. According to ''Ilta-Sanomat'' he has been on the Board of Directors of 120 companies.Vaatimaton miljonääri Ilta-Sanomat 12.6.2012 s.6-7 === Chempolis Involvement === Juha Sipilä was part-owner in the start-up company Chempolis. According to MOT Program (YLE) in 2012, Chempolis had received 10 million euros in public funds over 15 years along with extra funds from the Finnish Innovation Fund [[SITRA]] and Finnish state-owned financing company [[Finnvera]]. According to YLE TV News in 2017, the majority state-owned energy company [[Fortum]] saved Chempolis from bankruptcy by investing 6 million euros into the company in October 2016. Thereafter, children of Sipilä owned 5% of the company and Fortum 34%. Sipilä had been in control of the state owned companies including Fortum since the end of 2015. The Prime Ministers of Finland have not had the control of state companies previously.[http://yle.fi/uutiset/3-9395763 Valtionyhtiö Fortum pelasti konkurssikypsän teknologiayhtiön – omistajaohjauksesta vastaavan pääministeri Sipilän lapset yhtiön omistajina] YLE 10.1.2017 Prime Minister Juha Sipilä lobbied for Chempolis in India in 2016. Chempolis issued a press release on its joint venture with India's Numaligarh Refinery to build a biorefinery in North East India (Assam) for the production of bioethanol following meetings between Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]], India’s Finance Minister [[Arun Jaitley]] and Finland’s Prime Minister Juha Sipilä on 12–14 February 2016.[http://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/iltalehti_pm_lobbied_for_finnish_biotech_in_india_company_partly_owned_by_his_children_received_110_million_euro_deal/9395277 ltalehti: PM lobbied for Finnish biotech in India – company partly owned by his children received 110 million euro deal] YLE News 10.1.2017 ==Politics== As a student, Sipilä worked for a short time in the [[Finnish Centre Youth]], but otherwise he did not have experience in party politics before being elected to the Finnish Parliament in 2011 with 5,543 personal votes.[http://www.hs.fi/politiikka/Juha+Sipil%C3%A4+Keskustan+johtoon/a1305573721743 Juha Sipilä] accessed 9 June 2012{{cite web |url=http://www.hs.fi/english/print/1329104294448 |title=PROFILE: Juha Sipilä |author= Miska Rantanen |date=2012 |work= |publisher=Helsingin Sanomat |accessdate=28 June 2012}} In April 2012, Sipilä announced his candidacy for the chairman's position in the party congress of the summer. On June 9, 2012, the party congress elected him chairman. He beat [[Tuomo Puumala]] in the second round by 1251 to 872 delegate votes.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} Sipilä led his party to victory in the 2015 election, where the Centre Party gained 14 seats compared to the previous election. With 30,758 personal votes he was the most popular candidate in the election.{{cite web |url=http://tulospalvelu.vaalit.fi/E-2015/fi/kokomaaval.html |title=Valitut ehdokkaat Koko maa |date=22 April 2015 |publisher=Ministry of Justice |accessdate=9 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160625063910/http://tulospalvelu.vaalit.fi/E-2015/fi/kokomaaval.html |archivedate=25 June 2016 |df= }} Following the election, he was tasked with forming a government coalition; and as the leader of the Centre Party, he began formal negotiations with the [[Finns Party]] and the [[National Coalition Party]] and formed a [[Sipilä cabinet|three-party majority coalition]].{{cite web |url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/kolmen_assan_humppa__seuraa_hallitusohjelmavaantoa_smolnassa_hetki_hetkelta/7978517 |title= Kolmen ässän humppa – seuraa hallitusohjelmavääntöä Smolnassa hetki hetkeltä |date= 8 May 2015 |publisher=Yle |accessdate=9 May 2015}} ===Sipilä's Government=== Sipilä's government has struggled with Finland's poor economic performance,{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-35656150|title=Finland: The sick man of Europe?|last=Walker|first=Andrew|date=2016-02-29|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-06}} caused according to [[Paul Krugman]] and others by the constraints of its [[eurozone]] membership and aftershocks from the [[European debt crisis]],{{cite web|author1=[[Paul Krugman]]|title=Northern Discomfort|website=The Conscience of a Liberal|publisher=''[[New York Times]]''|accessdate=26 October 2016|location=https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/05/29/northern-discomfort/|date=29 May 2015}}{{cite web|author1=[[Paul Krugman]]|title=The Finnish Disease|website=The Conscience of a Liberal|publisher=''[[New York Times]]''|accessdate=26 October 2016|location=https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/06/01/the-finnish-disease/?_r=0|date=1 June 2015}} but also by the decline of the paper industry, the fall of [[Nokia]] and a diminution in exports to [[Russia]].{{Cite news|url=https://euobserver.com/beyond-brussels/132860|title=In Finland, the euro is not the real problem|last=|first=|date=|work=|publisher=|newspaper=EUobserver|access-date=2016-11-06|via=}}{{Cite web|url=http://bruegel.org/2015/12/finland-and-asymmetric-shocks/|title=Finland and asymmetric shocks {{!}} Bruegel|website=bruegel.org|access-date=2016-11-06}}{{cite web|last1=Walker|first1=Andrew|title=Finland: The sick man of Europe?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-35656150|website=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=14 November 2016|date=29 February 2016}}{{cite web|title=Finland's economic winter|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business-and-finance/21689751-nordic-laggard-can-forge-ahead-reforms|website=''[[The Economist]]''|accessdate=14 November 2016}} Its attempts to address the problems through policies of spending cuts and reducing labour costs have been controversial, particularly cuts to education spending that are seen as threatening Finland's successful public education system.{{cite web|last1=MacDougall|first1=David|title=Down and Out in Helsinki|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/finland-economy-crisis-alexander-stubb-finnish-education/|website=[[Politico]]|accessdate=26 October 2016|date=18 May 2016}} These austerity measures have partly been implemented due to [[European Commission]] pressure, which has urged Finland to improve its adherence to the [[Stability and Growth Pact]]{{cite web|last1=Goulard|first1=Hortense|title=Commission tells six EU countries to cut budget deficit|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/commission-tells-six-eu-countries-to-cut-budget-deficit/|website=[[Politico]]|accessdate=26 October 2016|date=9 March 2016}} and reform its labour market to improve competitiveness.{{cite web|title=Council recommendation on the 2016 national reform programme of Finland and delivering a Council opinion on the 2016 stability programme of Finland|url=http://ec.europa.eu/europe2020/pdf/csr2016/csr2016_finland_en.pdf|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=26 October 2016|pages=4–5|date=18 May 2016|quote=(8) To restore Finland's competitiveness, the functioning of the labour market must be improved in several ways. On an aggregate level, wage increases have been moderate since the centrally agreed wage deal was agreed in late 2013. Under the agreement, the year-on-year increase in negotiated wages slowed from 1.3% in the last quarter of 2013 to 0.5 % in the fourth quarter of 2015. In June 2015, the social partners decided to extend the agreement into 2016. However, labour productivity growth has not yet recovered and therefore nominal unit labour costs are forecast to increase, albeit more slowly. Negotiations have been carried out to restore cost-competitiveness.}} On 22 July 2015, Sipilä announced his government's commitment to reducing Finnish wage costs by 5% by 2019, an [[internal devaluation]] caused by Finland's loss of the ability to devalue its currency to boost competitiveness.{{cite web|last1=Hirst|first1=Tomas|title=What's happening to Finland's economy?|url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2015/07/whats-happening-to-finland-economy/|website=[[World Economic Forum]]|accessdate=14 November 2016|date=23 July 2015}} There have been protests against the government's austerity measures.{{cite web|title=Finland: Economic forecast summary (June 2016)|url=http://www.oecd.org/economy/finland-economic-forecast-summary.htm|website=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]]|accessdate=14 November 2016}} In 2017 summer [[Finns Party|Finns]] [[Finns Party|Party]] split into two parties The [[Blue Reform]] and the current [[Finns Party]]. The Blue Reform members of the former Finns Party, including all ministers, remained in the government after the split. === Talvivaara and Yleisradio scandal === In 2016, Sipiläs close relatives were revealed to be part-owners of the bankrupt [[Talvivaara Mining Company]], later renamed and re-organised into the company Terrafame, which had received considerable funds from the Finnish government.[http://yle.fi/uutiset/3-9288420 Antaisitko 150 euroa Talvivaaran kaivokselle? Tavallaan annoit jo] 11.11.2016[http://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/firm_owned_by_pms_relatives_gets_half-million_euro_order_from_terrafame/9317488 Firm owned by PM's relatives gets half-million euro order from Terrafame] 25.11.2016 YLE[http://yle.fi/uutiset/3-9315671 Pääministerin sukulaisten omistamalla yrityksellä noin puolen miljoonan euron tilaus Terrafamesta] 25.11.2016 YLE A Parliamentary Ombudsman later decided that Sipilä didn't face a conflict of interest over mine deal.[http://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/parliamentary_ombudsman_to_decide_whether_pm_faced_conflict_of_interest_over_mine_deal/9320997 Parliamentary Ombudsman to decide whether PM faced conflict of interest over mine deal] 28.11.2016[https://yle.fi/uutiset/3-9434359 Oikeusasiamies: Pääministeri ei ollut esteellinen Terrafame-asiassa] However, it was later revealed that Sipilä had contacted [[Yleisradio]] in order to instruct them on how to report on the Talvivaara and Terrafame incidents, leading to suspicion that YLE had been politically pressured.{{cite web|title=Mistä pääministerin ja Ylen välisessä jupakassa on kyse? Yhteenveto kohun keskeisistä vaiheista|url=https://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/art-2000004890340.html|website=www.hs.fi|publisher=Helsingin Sanomat|accessdate=6 May 2018}} ==Personal life== ===Family=== Sipilä grew up in the small town of [[Puolanka]], northern Finland, east of Oulu, the firstborn of four children to mother Pirkko and father Pentti Sipilä, an elementary school teacher. In 1981, Sipilä married Minna-Maaria Juntunen at [[Oulu Cathedral]]. They have five children.{{cite web| url = http://www.iltasanomat.fi/kotimaa/art-1427787326707.html| title = Juha Sipilän suhde vaimoonsa alkoi 16-vuotiaana erikoisesta tarjouksesta| work = Iltasanomat| author=Mika Koskinen | date=March 31, 2015| accessdate = August 4, 2015}} Their youngest son, Tuomo (born in 1993), died on 18 February 2015.{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/juha_sipila_steps_back_from_election_campaign_after_son_dies/7815272|title=Juha Sipilä steps back from election campaign after son dies|publisher=[[Yle]]|date=19 February 2015|accessdate=19 February 2015}} ===Wood Gas Venture=== Sipilä is known for his interest in [[wood gas]] electricity generation, which began as a hobby. The cost to bring power to his summer cottage seemed too high, and he became interested in [[wood gas]]. First, he produced the electricity with wind power and with a diesel generator, but then he started building wood gas plants. He converted an old Chevrolet El Camino into "El Kamina" (''Kamiina'' means "stove" in Finnish.) powered by wood gas, with electronic control systems.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wZdPkrghUZM|title=El Kamina – häkäpönttöauto|date=4 June 2010|work=YouTube}} This hobby was spun off into a company, Volter Oy, which produces wood gas power plants. A 10-house [[ecovillage]] in Kempele is powered by one such power plant.{{cite web|url=http://volter.fi/fi/portfolio/kempeleen-ekokortteli/|title=Kempeleen ekokortteli|work=Volter}}{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/kempeleen_ekokortteli_pyrkii_energiaomavaraisuuteen/5888863|title=Kempeleen ekokortteli pyrkii energiaomavaraisuuteen|work=Yle Uutiset}} ===Religious affiliation=== The Sipiläs are members of Rauhan Sana (transl. "Word of Peace", affiliated in North America with [[Apostolic Lutheran Church of America|ALCA]]), a small [[Laestadian]] revivalist denomination within the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland|state Lutheran church of Finland]]. The Sipiläs first met at a Laestadian summer camp as teenagers. Sipilä has stated he does not consider himself a legalistic Laestadian, and in interviews he has carefully distinguished his own Laestadian denomination from his home region's other, predominant, exclusive Laestadian group ([[Conservative Laestadianism]]).{{cite web| url=http://www.iltalehti.fi/eduskuntavaalit-2015/2015041419515861_eb.shtml | title=Tällainen on Sipilän herätysliike – ei abortille ja eutanasialle | date = April 15, 2015 | accessdate = July 24, 2015 | work = Ilta-Lehti}}{{cite web| url = http://www.kaleva.fi/uutiset/oulu/sipila-linjasi-suhdettaan-lestadiolaisuuteen/594972/ | title = Sipilä linjasi suhdettaan lestadiolaisuuteen| work = Kaleva| date=May 30, 2012| accessdate = June 2, 2015}}{{cite web| url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-3029205/Finland-poll-leader-open-deal-eurosceptic-populists.html| title = Finland poll leader open to deal with eurosceptic populists| work = Daily Mail UK| date=April 7, 2015| accessdate = August 4, 2015}} The chairman of board in Juha Sipilä's religious community was his wife’s brother in 2015.[http://www.iltalehti.fi/eduskuntavaalit-2015/2015041419515861_eb.shtml Tällainen on Sipilän herätysliike - ei abortille ja eutanasialle] Iltalehti 15.4.2015 According to Juha Sipilä, in 2012 he participated in the International Christian Chamber of Commerce ICCC.[http://www.kaleva.fi/uutiset/oulu/sipila-linjasi-suhdettaan-lestadiolaisuuteen/594972/ Sipilä linjasi suhdettaan lestadiolaisuuteen] Kaleva 30.5.2012 == Electoral history == === Parliamentary elections === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Electoral district !! Votes !! Percentage !! Result |- | [[Finnish parliamentary election, 2011|2011]] || [[Oulu (electoral district)|Oulu]] || 5,543 || 2.27% || Elected |- | [[Finnish parliamentary election, 2015|2015]] || Oulu || 30,758 || 12.32% || Elected |} === Municipal elections === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Municipality !! Votes !! Percentage !! Result |- | [[Finnish municipal elections, 2012|2012]] || [[Kempele]] || 755 || 11.69% || Elected |} {{cite web|title=Information Service|url=http://tulospalvelu.vaalit.fi/indexe.html|website=vaalit.fi|publisher=Ministry of Justice of Finland|accessdate=1 July 2017}} ==Cabinets== * [[Sipilä Cabinet]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} *{{Commons-inline}} {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mari Kiviniemi]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Leader of the [[Centre Party (Finland)|Centre Party]]|years=2012–present}} {{s-inc}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Eero Heinäluoma]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Speaker of the Parliament of Finland|Speaker of the Parliament]]|years=2015}} {{s-aft|after=[[Maria Lohela]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Alexander Stubb]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Prime Minister of Finland]]|years=2015–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{CentrePartyFinlandLeaders}} {{FinnishPrimeMinisters}} {{European Council}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sipila, Juha}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Veteli]] [[Category:Finnish Lutherans]] [[Category:Centre Party (Finland) politicians]] [[Category:Prime Ministers of Finland]] [[Category:Speakers of the Parliament of Finland]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of Finland (2011–15)]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of Finland (2015–19)]] [[Category:Finnish businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Oulu alumni]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2018}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox book | italic title = Kitchen Con | name = Kitchen Con | image = Kitchen_Con.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = Trevor White | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = Food & Travel
Business
Finance | genre = Non-fiction | set_in = | publisher = Mainstream Publishing | publisher2 = | pub_date = 4 October, 2007 | english_pub_date = | published = | media_type = | pages = 272 | awards = | isbn = 978-1845962654 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} '''''Kitchen Con: Writing on the Restaurant Racket''''' is a book about the restaurant business written by restaurant critic [[Trevor White (food critic)|Trevor White]], who is also the editor of ''[[The Dubliner Magazine]]'' and of a restaurant guide in Ireland - ''The Dubliner 100 Best Restaurants''. The title of the book is a reference to ''[[Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly|Kitchen Confidential]]'' by [[Anthony Bourdain]]. In the book, White describes how he believes that diners are routinely duped, with reference to his own career and to some of the bigger names in what he calls "the racket", including [[Gordon Ramsay]], [[Jean-Christophe Novelli]] and the [[Michelin Guide]].{{cite web|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-55970-834-0|title=Nonfiction Book Review: Kitchen Con: Writing on the Restaurant Racket by Trevor White, Author Arcade Publishing $25 (229p) ISBN 978-1-55970-834-0|publisher=}} The book was published by [[Mainstream Publishing]] 5 September 2006. ==External links== *[http://www.kitchencon.com/ KitchenCon.com] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:2006 books]] [[Category:Business books]] {{business-book-stub}} {{food-book-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Laurits Christian Meulengracht |image = Laurits (Lars) Christian Meulengracht.jpg |image_size = 140 |caption = Laurits Christian Meulengracht c. 1890 |nationality = [[Denmark|Danish]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1837|2|14|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Aarhus]], Denmark |death_date = {{death date and age|1903|5|9|1837|2|14|df=y}} |death_place = [[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]] }} '''Laurits Christian Meulengracht''' or '''Laurits Christopher Meulengracht''' (14 February 1837 - 9 April 1903) was a [[Denmark|Danish]] businessman and [[brewer]] who became one of the wealthiest men in Denmark in the 19th century. He received the [[Order of the Dannebrog]] and [[Order of the Dannebrog|Knight of the Dannebrog]].<ref name="ACA">{{cite web |url=http://aarhuswiki.dk/wiki/Lars_Christian_Meulengracht_(1837-1903) |title=Lars Christian Meulengracht (1837-1903) |publisher=Aarhus City Archives |language=Danish |accessdate=12 September 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6kTKzHJ3h?url=http://aarhuswiki.dk/wiki/Lars_Christian_Meulengracht_(1837-1903) |archive-date=12 September 2016 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="Lund">{{cite web |url=http://www.lundskov.dk/menu/aarhusperson.htm |title=Meulengracht slægten |publisher=Lundskov |language=Danish |accessdate=12 September 2016 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130701052124/http://www.lundskov.dk/menu/aarhusperson.htm |archive-date=1 July 2013 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
His father Lars Christian Meulengracht died 6 months before he was born so he grew up in his grandfather [[Harboe Meulengracht]]'s house. 15 years old he started an internship in the store of Malthe Conrad Lottrup, a local businessman who among other things owned a sizable brewery. In 1858 he was sent to [[Copenhagen]] to study trade further and in 1862 he started a successful business in [[London]]. However, by 1870 his former mentor Malthe Conrad Lottrup had fallen ill and called Meulengracht home to take over management of Lottrup's [[Ceres Brewery]].<ref name="DSD">{{cite web|url=http://denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/H%C3%A5ndv%C3%A6rk/Brygger/L._Chr._Meulengracht |title=L. Chr. Meulengracht |publisher=[[Gyldendal]]'s Encyclopedia ''Den Store Danske'' |language=Danish |accessdate=12 September 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6kTL0XR6f?url=http://denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/H%C3%A5ndv%C3%A6rk/Brygger/L._Chr._Meulengracht |archive-date=12 September 2016 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="Grav">{{cite web|url=http://www.gravsted.dk/person.php?navn=lcmeulengracht |title=Laurits Chr. Meulengracht |publisher=Gravsted |language=Danish |accessdate=12 September 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6kTL2RWv6?url=http://www.gravsted.dk/person.php?navn=lcmeulengracht |archive-date=12 September 2016 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
Meulengracht took over the brewery and managed it through a lifetime. Initially he rationalized and bought new technology in the form of an [[steam engine]]. In the years 1872-88 a large expansion program was undertaken that eventually made Ceres the largest brewery in [[Jutland]] and Meulengracht one of the wealthiest people in Aarhus. Tax records show he paid more in taxes than even contemporary [[Otto Mønsted]] and [[Hans Broge]]. Meulengracht eventually moved into a new home on the Ceres-complex which eventually became a social focal point for the local upper class. As an employer he was known for his ability to make opposing groups work together and privately Meulengracht was active in charity and advocacy work. In 1876 he was elected to the city council and held his seat for 14 years, working in numerous committees particularly on public works and infrastructure. Meulengracht was also one of the forces behind the establishment [[Aarhus Theatre]] and he sat on the first board after it was opened.<ref name="ACA"/><ref name="DSD"/>
Laurits Meulengracht died 9 April 1903, after lengthy illness and during a healing trip to [[Monte Carlo]]. He was buried on [[Nordre Cemetery]] in Aarhus.
== Honors == Meulengracht had the official honorary title of ''etatsråd'' and he received the [[Order of the Dannebrog]] and [[Order of the Dannebrog|Knight of the Dannebrog]].<ref name="DSD"/>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{COI|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Lauritz Dippenaar | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1948|10|25}} | birth_place = | residence = [[Johannesburg]], South Africa | alma mater = [[University of Pretoria]] | networth = [[United States dollar|$]] 650 million <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/lauritz-laurie-dippenaar/|title=Lauritz (Laurie) Dippenaar|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref> | nationality = [[South African]] | occupation = Businessman | known_for = Dippenaar Scholarship | children = Three }}
'''Lauritz Laurie Dippenaar''' is a South African self made millionaire businessman,investor & banker who is the Chairman of [[FirstRand]] financial Group. He is also well known for his philanthropic activities and runs a scholarship programme through his generous endowments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstrand.co.za/csi/Pages/laurie-dippenaar-scholarship.aspx|title=Pages - laurie dippenaar scholarship|website=Firstrand.co.za|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref>
==Biography== Lauritz Dippenaar graduated from [[Pretoria University]] with a [[Master of Commerce]], qualified as a [[South_African_Institute_of_Chartered_Accountants|Chartered Accountant]] with [[KPMG]], and spent three years with the Industrial Development Corporation of South Africa. In 1977, Dippenaar founded FirstRand's predecessor, Rand Consolidated Investing along with Paul Harris and [[Gerrit Ferreira]].He served as executive chairman of RMB from 1992 until the formation of FirstRand in 1998. He was appointed as the first chief executive of [[FirstRand]] and held this position until the end of 2005 when he was selected as a chairman for a non-executive role in 2008.
==Philanthropy== He sponsors the Laurie Dippenaar Postgraduate Scholarship for International Study. The scholarship is awarded annually and is available to a South African citizen, for study outside South Africa in any discipline at the internationally recognized University of their choice for a Postgraduate degree. It has a value R350 000 ($37,000) per annum for a maximum of two years.
==Personal life== Dippenaar is married with three children. His hobbies include watching rugby, Canoeing and cycling.
==Financial and legal controversies== A press release dated August 27, 2014 featured that US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) issued an order filing and settling charges against FirstRand Bank Ltd (under the chairmanship of Lauritz Laurie Dippenaar) and imposed a $150,000 civil monetary penalty for executing unlawful prearranged, non-competitive trades involving corn and soybean futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT), a designated contract market of the CME Group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/pr6985-14|title=CFTC Orders FirstRand Bank, Ltd. to Pay $150,000 Civil Monetary Penalty for Unlawfully Executing Prearranged, Noncompetitive Trades on the CBOT|website=Cftc.gov|access-date=2017-07-18}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dippenaar, Lauritz}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Afrikaner people]] [[Category:White South African people]] [[Category:South African businesspeople]]

In [[olive oil extraction]], '''malaxation''' ([[Latin]] ''malaxare'', [[Greek language|Greek]] '''''μαλακος''''' meaning "soft") is the action of slowly churning or mixing milled [[olive]]s, typically for 20 to 40 minutes. The churning allows the smaller droplets of [[oil]] released by the milling process to aggregate and be more easily separated. The paste is normally heated to around 27 °C during this process. Oil yield is proportional to the temperature and mixing time. However, the use of higher temperatures and longer mixing times increases [[oxidation]] of the oil and therefore decreases shelf life, so a compromise must be struck. Also, the usage of higher temperatures does not allow for the labelling of the oil as "cold extracted", a term used widely as a marketing tactic, especially in the [[European Union]].
It is now possible with newer equipment to use a blanket of [[inert gas]] such as [[nitrogen]] or [[carbon dioxide]] over the olive paste, which greatly reduces oxidation. This allows for an increased yield without compromising the quality of the oil.
After malaxation is complete, the paste is sent to a phase separator. Nearly all producers use a [[decanter centrifuge]] for this process. Traditionally the olive oil was separated from the paste using a large press that was either screwed down or weighted with rocks.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== *[[Olive oil extraction]]

{{unreferenced|date=February 2015}}{{Infobox company | name = Mitsubishi Caterpillar Forklift America Inc. | type = [[Private company|Private]] | slogan = | foundation = 1992 | location = [[Houston, Texas]], United States | industry = [[Manufacturing]] & [[Distribution (business)|Distribution]] | products = [[Machinery]] | homepage = http://www.mcfa.com/ }}
'''Mitsubishi Caterpillar Forklift America Inc.''' ("MCFA"), headquartered in [[Houston, Texas]] is a manufacturer and distributor of material handling equipment and parts under the [[Mitsubishi Forklift Trucks]], Cat Lift Trucks, and Jungheinrich brand names. MCFA also owns the rights to [[Towmotor]] brand name, but does not manufacture under it. MCFA is ISO 9001-2000 certified and has obtained compliance certification from the California Air Resources Board (CARB). MCFA provides a full line of forklifts with complete sales and product support through more than 400 dealer locations throughout the United States, Canada and Latin America.
The company's {{convert|860000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. facility in Houston is located on {{convert|42|acre|m2}} of land and employs 1,200 workers, capable of producing over 25,000 forklifts per annum.
MCFA is a subsidiary of [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries]] and one of the worldwide MCF group of companies:
* [[Mitsubishi Caterpillar Forklift Europe B.V.|MCFE (Mitsubishi Caterpillar Forklift Europe B.V.)]] based in Almere, [[Netherlands]] * MCFS (Mitsubishi Caterpillar Forklift Asia Pte Ltd.) based in [[Singapore]]
Each group, with the exception of MCFS, is responsible for design engineering, manufacturing and marketing the product lines and handling parts distribution in their respective regions.
==History== MCFA was formed through a joint venture in 1992 between two major companies, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd. (MHI) and Caterpillar Industrial Inc. (CII). Jungheinrich Forklifts joined this partnership on January 1, 2010 through a manufacturing and distribution agreement with MCFA.
==Products==
*Internal Combustion Cushion Tire Lift Trucks *Internal Combustion Pneumatic Tire Lift Trucks *Electric Counterbalanced Forklifts *Electric Narrow Aisle Forklift Trucks *Electric and Manual Walkie Forklifts
